title: 108_s377
content:
The Act is titled the "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Commemorative Coin Act of 2003". Congress acknowledges Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s dedication to securing liberty and justice for all citizens, his leadership in the civil rights movement, his iconic "I Have A Dream" speech, advocacy for nonviolence, and the importance of commemorating his legacy. Efforts are underway to secure the personal papers of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. for the Library of Congress to preserve and study for future generations. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins with specific specifications, including weight, diameter, and metal composition. The coins will be legal tender. Silver for minting will be sourced from various available sources, including stockpiles. The design of the coins will be determined. The design of the coins minted under this Act will reflect Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s human rights legacy. The coins will feature inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "2003", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated mint facility. The Secretary may only issue these coins during a one-year period starting on January 15, 2004.

SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a $10 surcharge per coin, and the costs of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. All surcharges from coin sales under this Act will be promptly paid by the Secretary to the Library of Congress for purchasing and maintaining historical documents related to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
